title: The Power of Open Data

author: Florian Bauer, Renewable Energy and Energy Efficiency Partnership (REEEP)

segmentation: Yeah my name is Florian Bauer.
I'm working for the renewable energy and Energy Efficiency Partnership.

It's nonprofit organization working mainly in developing countries and emerging markets on clean energy and energy efficiency, and one of our main topics that we're working on is also data, open data, linked open data.
Because we think that this is actually something that can help the uptake of clean energy and energy efficiency in developing countries.
And I kindly was invited to talk here about the power of open data and I will give you some examples of how open data I think can be very powerful in the field of clean energy.
And also in developing countries.
So I want.
Start with this one, which is a tech cloud from a workshop that in the city of Edmond was done.
They talked about open government data and this is A tag cloud that I really like because you very well see that there are two main topics that are of great interest.
One is about data Accessibility of data, the availability of data, openness of data, and the and the other one is about standards and context and so on.
And I want to focus on these two topics in my presentation.
So let's start with.
Yeah, well, we heard yesterday from Minister Shatter this figure of 2.5 quintillion bytes of data.
And as some others, I also ask myself, what the hell are 2.5 quintillion bytes of data.
I had no clue.
And ice also, in the in the Twitter feed that some people looked it up on Wikipedia, and Dan posted it.
And I did that too, because I was interested how much it was, and I looked it up and this came out and I wasn't.
I didn't know.
More about that after I looked it up because it's 2.5 with 17 zeros.
Well, that's interesting.
Try to do some calculations.
It's about 3.5 billion of HD movies, which makes it a little bit better understandable for me.
The next question I asked myself.
It is well, why is this not enough?
Why do we still have to talk about all of this?
Why is this not solving our problems?
What is needed and what are the challenges?
Well, for me it's three main challenges that I want to raise.
One.
The first one is data is kept in silos very often, and we all know that, and we know that this is a common issue.

We very often see that especially in developing countries, you knock on the door of a government and say look, I really would like to have this data set to build a new interesting project to reduce the risk of my investment and so on.
And you here, well, you can't have it.
The second one is that raw data is still very often part of a business model, and it's sold, so this is another challenge we are facing and I think this will change, but it will take some time.
And the third one, especially in developing countries, is that it's very often not digitized yet.
So we are facing a very big challenge in trying to get paperwork into machine readable formats.
Hopefully not like with the guy on the on the picture.
And of course there is a four 4 phone that I don't want to discuss now because we just discussed in lots of the talks previously is about analyzing this massive amounts of data.
So the question is, is this important for clean energy?
And the clear answer from my side is yes and we heard already some talks in the last one day and also today that energy is a sector where data is very relevant.
Actually we heard yesterday from Fiona about smart grids we had today about oil and then.
We see that data is very, very relevant factor in energy and in clean energy.
But to find out what is real.
Irrelevant in clean energy.
We talked to our project implementers.
We are the renewable energy and Energy Efficiency partnership.
We have funding projects in developing countries, so we look for really good project implementers in those countries to make this project happen.
To implement this project, we don't do them ourselves.
We are funding them.
We're project managing them.
We're helping them, but we don't do them ourselves.
And we have this project implementers that meet once a year and where we come together and do some peer learning sessions.
And in the last session we ask them look, we were thinking about open data.
What could help you?
And I want to show you one quite interesting example.
It is about a project that we are funding on low emission transportation in Jakarta.
You know all these megacities, especially in emerging markets.
They have a massive issue with traffic.
Sometimes you need a day to go from one end to the city to the other end, because it's just a massive traffic jam and that already that also includes issues with air quality, CO2 emissions and so on.
And what we try to do in this project is that we try to solve that by implementing a trend trunk feeder transportation system.
So basically implementing bus lanes and and implementing a system that brings people from A to be much more efficient.
And the impact of that is a lot of fuel savings.
That's the one hand side, and the other hand side is of course we're trying to use buses with cleaner and cleaner fuel like natural gas, and that saves to you to the CO2 emissions.
And we talked to the project implement and said look where where is your point?
How could we help you with open data?
And it was quite interesting because.
Our project implementer said well, I had to spend lots of my time and lots of your money in trying to get the basic datasets that I need to implement this project.
And they need to do that by themselves at the moment.
What they need is geographic demographic data of the city.
How is the population distributed?
Web where people going, where they're working, all datasets that we think, well, that should be somewhere and they said yes, it's there.
But we can't simply can't get it.
We can't get it from the government if we get it, we get it in a form that it's not useful for us where we can can't work with it automatically, and that actually took a lot of their time.
And it took a lot of effort for them to do it.
So in.
That context linked open data, for example, could help them to avoid replicating of what is already there, which is unnecessary work.
Unnecessary spending of money.
They could concentrate on their own experience instead of collecting data they could concentrate on their experience on implementing an efficient transportation system.
Of course, it also helps them would help them to keep data maintenance to a minimum because they are now collecting the data they have to keep it updated, which again this effort and and and.
Expensive.
And of course, if they would have all the data sets available, this would create new knowledge because they could build something new on that.
And that's actually one example of where open data is very powerful.
Also, Aiden clean Energy in developing countries and so on.
I just want to show you one quick example.
We're open, data was very powerful for us as an organization.
We're running a portal that's called regal.info.
It's clean Energy Information portal, and we want to make information on clean energy accessible to a lot of users.
And one thing that we do is this country energy, energy profiles where we collect lots of information on energy in all countries in the world.
We collect them from the pedia from the UN Euro stats, the World Bang, our own databases, and so on.
Much more.
And of course we would never be able to do that without open data because we would have to have.
Team of 10 people constantly working on updating this and this is a tool that worked very well and that drove lots of users to our portal and we have quite a good number of users there.
So what I think is needed also in developing countries is to publish more data to publish data in rowing machine readable formats.
With licenses that allowed to reuse them and we have to start linking datasets on a data on data level an.
We therefore decided that we want to go into this part of the of the game.

We we therefore decided that we want to fund energy projects, clean energy projects that are data related in in developing countries and for example, we started with one project that we are now starting to fund and to run and to support in Ghana where we help them to build an open database on energy access related data.
The second thing that's not only here is we just hiring a new member of the team, concentrating exactly on this.
So we put lots of effort on this and I would be happy to talk to anyone who is interested in helping us with that or doing some projects with us on that.
Let's come back to this tag cloud.
I said two things are important.
One is data and the other one is standards and context.
And I want to briefly go into the topic of of context and standards.
Would I have learned in my past seven years of working in that field is.
You know knowledge broker portals.
This portals are created every day and I'm pretty sure everyone of you has the same feeling when you open up your emails in the morning and you see oh, another portal created every day.
We receive these messages and I think it's very hard to prevent this, which has several reasons.
So we have to cope with that and I think one possibility to do that is to at least connect portals that are created and make the message in those portals consistent and connect related content.
So there is a strong need in increasing the consistency when tagging and describing documents.
I think 'cause you have lots of portals talking about the same things and describing them in a different way which is not good.
That also means that we need to ensure the consistency of the message 'cause if.
Different portals talk about same things in a different way.
This creates uncertainty.
This confuses the users.
It's not good for all of us.
And I think what we need is the standardization of using categories and tags in describing data in describing information in describing knowledge.
The question that we asked ourself is can we support that with an automated system and my answer to that is yes we have to.
We are now working with the World Bank for example they have hundreds thousands of documents on deforestation and the challenge for them was how the hell do we ever categorized them and the 1st?
Idea of them was, well, we will hire 100 interns and let them three years.
Read them through all the documents and put categories on it.
Well, this will not work.
This will end up in a big mess with different tags, different categories used, and as we heard yesterday from Bale, it's very hard to read through documents on the long term.
You know, people stop giving having attention after a few minutes and the tagging will not be as good as it could be with an automated system.
So the next question we asked ourselves, what does an automated system have to be able to do to be useful?
One is of course to understand synonyms and relations, and I've just taking a nap visualization of the Internet, the Internet map.
There is a document on one website contact with multiple tag, another one text with PV where the system has to understand that this is the same.
Another

One is dealing with disambiguation and, well, this is a planned and this is a plant the system has to understand out of the context of documents, which of the plans is meant, and I have to tell you this is a real life example.

We got some contribution of government helping us in translating our tesouros on clean energy terms and we ended up in having the French translate translation of plant with a flower which wasn't very useful in our context.
So we have to have a system that understands the context and is able to deal with that.

And of course we have to utilize the power of linked open data, I think because when we have this tagging systems they our system is based on a very extensive clean energy climate change to sorrows and just basing it on this one this hours I think is not enough.
We have to base it on to.

Sorry that are based on linked open data and our tesouros for example is connected to various different other ones while using linked open data and we of course provide our tesouros fully as linked open data for everyone to reuse.
So let me just.
Run this quickly through this new tool that we developed, which is an API.
It's called the Regal tagging API and it helps users in a consistent way.
So let's assume you have lots of unstructured data like we had with the World Bank.
For example, lots of documents, massive amount of pages on different documents, and structured.
But we can do.
With with the tagging API, we can turn this unstructured documents into knowledge and we do that by.
Providing a service where you can send send in files automatically, the tagging API is annaleigh.
Using it based on our tesouros that is in the back of the system which is using linked open data.
We extract the most.
Relevant terms and this is already very important, I think 'cause it is an automated system extracting the most relevant terms of these documents based on knowledge that is built into sorrows.
We also extract you geographic locations, which is very often very, very important in categorizing documents.
And we provide all the information that we have as additional information in the tesouros to the users.
For example, definitions, synonyms, links to other tesori and so on.
Just want to give you a quick example.
I have taken today.

In the morning I have taken A blog entry from the OKF and blog about sustainable energy and policy demands and so on, and I've run that through the API and what comes out of that is is the result with the tags extracted based on the tesouros you see all the text with the scores, some locations extracted out of the document and if you go into more detail you will find all the additional information from the desirous like the synonyms, the broader narrower terms.
And of course, the UI to the concept.
So if you're interested in that, have a look on that the tagging API's for free said we're nonprofit organization, so we're providing that for free.
It's funded by different governments, UK, Germany and so on, and I would like to encourage you to have a look on that.
I'm.
And this is my last topic about.
Telling you that open data is really powerful, it's really powerful in increasing your audience and we have heard about that several times.
Very often it's very, very important to disseminate what you know to share what you know, and especially if it's publicly funded.
It's very important about that and I just want to show you our users user statistics on Regal, which is going from 2008 from about 500 five 100,000 users a year.
Unique visitors a year to now 2.5 million unique users a year.

And this is mainly based, I think on our use of open data becausw we can provide very useful services based on the datasets that others are developing datasets that others are maintaining and we can concentrate on providing them in a useful context.
And this is actually very, very powerful I think.
And these features are not taking into concern all the visibility that our data gets by sharing it in other portals via using open data.
Um?
That's it, from my side.
I would like to encourage you to have a look on Regal Info and the API.
If you have any questions I will be at the pool party semantic Web table outside during the lunch break.

Becausw Pool Party is the software we are using and if you have any questions on the tagging API and other stuff that I talked about come to me, I will be there and I will be happy to answer questions.
Thank you.
Quitters McManus from this team and actually representative of Language technology which your talk was all about.
Yes, the problems are there if you move from the string to the meaning which has to be the goal of any data community.
Then you indeed need all of the things that you mentioned, including.
The semantics of meaning, including ontologies that are linked to monolingual information, and.
Synonyms and disambiguation issues, and I wish you all welcome to our panel in about an hour.
Hi Michael, it's from the Joint Research Centre of the European Commission.
Just a quick statement and a short question on the standards that you mentioned for data exchange or for vocabularies too to tag information.
I wanted to point you to the to inspire Directive and the associated implementing rules which probably are aware of.
We've developed data models and vocabularies for a number of environmental themes, including energy resources including mineral resource is and.

Climate as well, so that might be something that will be useful to you, because it's also going to be translated in all the European languages, so that might be useful resource for you to add to your your thesaurus network and the question is about the developing countries and the data collection that you're doing there.
Have you considered using citizen information volunteered?
Information coming from people?
If you if you cannot get access from from.
Government to government data and have you encountered any or are you dealing with any of the problems that are related to that?
Just that kind of data collection?
Yeah, I think we will have to.
The answer is we don't at the moment, but we will have to.
I think because it is incredibly hard to get all data you need from developing countries.
I mean, there are some good examples of developing countries opening up data like Kenya and Ghana and so on, but I think.
The approach to work with citizens will be very important.
I totally agree to that and thanks for the for the remark on languages.
Just want to say that the API's working with documents in Spanish, French, Portuguese, German and English.
So it's the languages are a very important issue and I think that needs to increase also in terms of what languages can be dealt with.
OK thanks a lot Mr Bauer.
